<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_map:
```c
int metal_dma_map(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_in,
		  int nents_in,
		  struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int nents_out;

	if (!dev || !sg_in || !sg_out)
		return -EINVAL;
	if (!dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map)
		return -ENODEV;

	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/* If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);
	nents_out = dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg_in, nents_in, sg_out);
	return nents_out;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags:
int		(*dev_dma_map)(struct metal_bus *bus,
					       struct metal_device *device,
					       uint32_t dir,
					       struct metal_sg *sg_in,
					       int nents_in,
					       struct metal_sg *sg_out);

nents_out = dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg_in, nents_in, sg_out);
explanation: There is no direct call to metal_dma_map within its own body (no explicit metal_dma_map(...) invocation), so direct recursion is not present. The only potential recursion path is via the function-pointer dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_map: its declaration and the runtime call site are the relevant locations to inspect because an implementation of that bus operation could (intentionally or accidentally) call back into metal_dma_map, creating indirect recursion. Other code in the function (null checks, atomic_thread_fence calls, local variable use, and return of nents_out) cannot introduce self-calls. The other members of struct metal_bus_ops shown have different signatures (and thus cannot be the same function pointer as dev_dma_map without a type mismatch), so they are not relevant to Rule 17.2 in this context. Therefore only the dev_dma_map function-pointer declaration and its null-check and invocation sites need further investigation for possible indirect recursion.
